title-group.article-title: Cyclical Demand and the Choice of Debt Maturity*

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2001 by The University of Chicago. All rights reserved.

abstract.p: This study provides a model in which a supplier’s use of short‐ and long‐term debt depends on the demand for its product. The model predicts that suppliers use short‐term debt to match their assets' and liabilities' maturities and that their incentive to do so is stronger, the larger the term premium. The model also predicts that the use of short‐term debt increases the amplitudes of the supplier’s investment, production, and sales cycles. These changes occur because the use of short‐term debt permits suppliers to match production and sales more closely to the pattern of demand for the final good.

fn.p: An earlier version of this article was presented at Universidade Católica Portuguesa and the 1998 Financial Management Association meeting. Scott C. Linn, Manuela A. Marques, Bryan E. Stanhouse, and an anonymous referee provided helpful comments. This research was funded in part by a Ronn Lytle Research Fellowship awarded by the Center for Financial Studies at the University of Oklahoma.

sec.label: I.
sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Companies use both short‐ and long‐term loans to finance their short‐ and long‐term assets. The sources of debt available to them include commercial paper and bonds with terms to maturity of a few days and 30 or more years, respectively. This is a wide range of terms to maturity, and we only partially understand how companies make their choices from these alternatives and how their choices affect them. While there are studies of how asymmetric information, contracting costs, and taxes affect the choice of short‐ and long‐term debt, there are no studies of the relationships among the demand for a company’s product, its ensuing requirement for assets, and this choice.

The illustration in figure1indicates that this subject deserves a close examination because there is a strong relationship between the demand for a company’s product and its financing choice. This figure is a graph of toy companies’ quarterly sales, assets, and debt from 1989 to 1997. The demand for toys is highly seasonal, with retail sales concentrated in the fourth quarter. Toy companies’ sales behave similarly, peaking in the third or fourth quarter. Figure1shows that toy companies’ total assets and total debt follow the same pattern as their sales with the variations resulting from seasonal changes in short‐term assets that are financed by seasonal changes in short‐term debt. Similar pictures emerge in other industries with cyclical demand. Fig. 1.—
Quarterly sales, assets, and debt of toy companies, first quarter 1989–fourth quarter 1997. Sales is Compustat data item 2 (net sales), total assets is Compustat data item 44 (total assets), total debt is Compustat data item 54 (total liabilities), plant and equipment is Compustat data item 42 (total net property, plant, and equipment), and long‐term debt is Compustat data item 51 (total long‐term debt). Compustat PC+ provides quarterly balance sheet information for 33 companies in SICs 3942 (dolls and stuffed toys) and 3944 (games, toys, and children’s vehicles). Eleven of these companies were eliminated because their fiscal year did not end in December, and 14 companies were eliminated because data were not available for the entire period. Included companies from SIC 3942 are Mattel and Russ Berrie & Co. Included companies from SIC 3944 are Action Products International, Empire of Carolina, Galoob Toys, Hasbro, Ohio Art Co., and Stuart Entertainment.

This study examines the relationship between the demand for a company’s product and its use of short‐ and long‐term debt, thereby providing an explanation for the financing practices illustrated in figure1. This explanation is based on a model in which a supplier’s financing requirement depends on the demand for its product, which is used to produce a final good that is subject to cyclical demand.1The supplier’s optimal plant size, output, and borrowing are simultaneously determined in this model to permit a comprehensive analysis of the effects of its financing choice. The model predicts when the use of short‐term debt is economical and how it affects a supplier’s operations and investments.

The model predicts that the optimal use of short‐term debt increases a supplier’s output and profit even though it increases the amplitude of the demand cycle. These changes occur because the use of short‐term debt alters the supplier’s long‐run marginal costs and permits it to match more closely the production and sale of its product to the pattern of demand for the final good. The prediction that the use of short‐term debt increases the supplier’s output is especially important because an increase in production must be accompanied by an increase in capacity and inventory. That is, the use of short‐term debt affects a company’s investment policy. This relationship implies that the use of short‐term loans is an important part of a company’s overall operating and financing strategy.

This model explains two of the more important results of recent empirical tests of the determinants of corporate debt maturity. First, the model predicts that companies use short‐term debt to avoid the term premium in long‐term interest rates. This prediction was confirmed by Guedes and Opler (1996) and Stohs and Mauer(1996), who found a negative association between the slope of the yield curve and the maturity of corporate debt. The model’s prediction and Guedes and Opler’s and Stohs and Mauer’s results contrast sharply with the predictions of the tax‐based theories of debt maturity structure that hypothesize a positive relationship between the slope of the yield curve and the use of long‐term debt.

Second, the model predicts that companies avoid the term premium by matching the maturity of their assets and liabilities. This prediction was also confirmed by Guedes and Opler (1996) and Stohs and Mauer (1996) as well as Demirgüç‐Kunt and Maksimovic (1999), who found strong evidence of maturity matching. Demirgüç‐Kunt and Maksimovic’s results were particularly interesting because they found that companies used a larger proportion of short‐term debt the higher their sales‐to‐fixed‐assets ratio. This result suggests that companies use short‐term debt to finance assets that vary with sales levels, such as inventory and accounts receivable, as predicted by this model.

This study’s basis for these and other predictions is markedly different from previous explanations for the use of short‐ and long‐term debt.2One group of explanations was based on asymmetric information. Flannery (1986) and Kale and Noe (1990) focused on asymmetric information about asset quality and predicted that high‐quality companies use short‐term debt to signal their type. Diamond (1991,1993) showed that liquidity risk may force even low‐quality companies to use short‐term debt, leaving only intermediate quality companies to issue long‐term debt. Barclay and Smith (1995), Guedes and Opler (1996), and Stohs and Mauer (1996) confirmed Diamond’s predictions, although only Stohs and Mauer’s results were consistent with Flannery’s and Kale and Noe’s predictions. Hart and Moore (1994) were concerned with asymmetric information about the entrepreneur’s intentions to abide by his commitments and predicted that companies will match the maturity of their assets and liabilities. Goswami (1999) focused on asymmetric information about asset maturity and concluded that all companies will issue long‐term debt unless there are transaction costs, in which case companies with short‐term assets will issue long‐term debt and vice versa. Hart and Moore’s prediction is consistent with the maturity matching results described above, although Goswami’s prediction of maturity mismatching is not.

Another group of explanations was based on contracting costs. Myers (1977) argued that the use of short‐term debt diminishes the underinvestment problem by ensuring that the owners receive the benefits from exercising profitable growth options. At the same time, he noted that concern about contracting costs may explain why companies match the maturity of their liabilities to the maturity of their assets in place. Barnea, Haugen, and Senbet (1980) stated that the use of short‐term loans may diminish the asset substitution problem because the value of short‐term debt is less sensitive to changes in the value of the underlying asset. Barclay and Smith’s (1995) and Guedes and Opler’s (1996) results were consistent with the contracting cost explanation, although Stohs and Mauer’s (1996) results, with the exception of their finding of maturity matching, were not.

The final group of explanations for the use of short‐ and long‐term debt was based on taxes. Brick and Ravid (1985) showed that the interaction of borrowers’ preferences for accelerating interest tax shields and lenders’ preferences for delaying the recognition of interest income can cause borrowers to prefer long‐term debt when the yield curve is upward sloping and vice versa. In a subsequent article, Brick and Ravid (1991) demonstrated that this preference for long‐term debt extends to flat and sometimes downward sloping yield curves when interest rates are uncertain. Their alternative interpretation of these results, that long‐term debt is optimal when the term premium is positive, is inconsistent with the empirical results described above. Along a different line, Mauer and Lewellen (1987) argued that companies can use long‐term debt to obtain the valuable tax‐timing option provided by the opportunity to refinance when the tax effect is favorable to the owners. Kim, Mauer, and Stohs (1995) extended this analysis to consider investors’ tax‐timing options and predicted that companies will use more long‐term debt when interest rates are volatile and the yield curve is upward sloping. Their empirical results supported the volatility prediction, but the evidence regarding the slope of the yield curve was inconclusive. Stohs and Mauer (1996) found some support for a tax effect on the use of short‐ and long‐term debt, while Barclay and Smith (1995) and Guedes and Opler (1996) found none.

There are two important differences between this study and the ones described above. First, this study examines the relationships among the demand for a company’s product, its requirement for assets, and its financing choice instead of the effects of asymmetric information, contracting costs, or taxes. In fact, in this model, information is symmetric, there is complete certainty, the supplier’s investment opportunity set is fully described at the outset, and there are no taxes. Second, this study focuses on systematic changes in the use of debt rather than the level of debt or changes in the level that arise from sporadic financing decisions. These differences imply that this study’s explanation for the use of short‐ and long‐term debt complements the other explanations because financing choices made in response to asymmetric information, and so on, can coexist with choices related to cyclical variations in production and sales. Consequently, this study improves our understanding of the use of short‐ and long‐term debt by examining a potentially important determinant of this financing choice that is not considered elsewhere in the literature.

The remainder of this article is organized as follows. Section II establishes the model and describes its key optimality conditions, which are expressed in terms of the supplier’s long‐run marginal costs. Section III derives the necessary conditions for using some short‐term debt and uses these conditions to determine how short‐term debt affects the supplier’s long‐run marginal costs. Section IV describes how the use of short‐term debt affects the supplier’s operations and the buyer’s profits. Section V provides a numerical example that illustrates the model’s properties. Section VI concludes the article with a discussion of empirical predictions.

fn.p: A cycle less than 12 months long is commonly called a seasonal cycle, although the model developed here is applicable to a cycle of any length.

Aigner and Sprenkle (1973) also developed a model of how companies choose the mix of short‐ and long‐term debt to use when financing cyclical cash needs. However, their company’s need for cash was exogenously determined, and their main result required that the interest rate on short‐term loans exceed the interest rate on long‐term loans (see Grace1975). In contrast, the supplier’s investment, output, and financing requirements are simultaneously determined in this study, and the yield curve can be upward sloping, downward sloping, or flat.

sec.label: II.
sec.title: The Model
sec.p: This section establishes the model by describing market demand, the supplier’s production and financing alternatives, and its optimization problem.

sec.label: A.
sec.title: Market Demand
sec.p: The supplier manufactures a product that is purchased by other firms. This product may be an intermediate good that is purchased by other manufacturers or a final good that is purchased by wholesalers or retailers. The supplier’s customers are represented by a single stand‐in firm, hereafter called “the buyer.”

fn.p: The derived demand functions represent market demand and, therefore, must account for the entire market’s attitude to holding additional inventory. The market could exhibit increasing resistance to holding inventory as assumed here because each individual firm actually faces increasing costs or because individual firms have constant but different inventory costs.

Emery (1987) showed that the supplier can extend trade credit to the buyer and thereby narrow the difference between marginal revenue in the two periods if the buyer has a higher opportunity cost. This method of accommodating cyclical demand is not available here because both parties face the same term structure of interest rates.

sec.label: B.
sec.title: The Supplier’s Method of Production
sec.p: The supplier purchases the optimal quantity of its single variable input at the beginning of each period and manufactures its product for sale at the end of each period. The supplier’s method of production is one of the alternatives Crew and Kleindorfer (1979) described in their review of the theory of peak‐load pricing. The first alternative is to install a single large plant that is operated at capacity during the peak period and at less than capacity during the off‐peak period. The second alternative is to install two plants: a primary facility that is fully employed both periods to meet continuing demand and a secondary facility that is operated at capacity during the peak period to supply the extra demand. The third alternative is to install a single plant with the capacity to meet average demand, operate it at full capacity during both periods, and inventory excess first‐period production for sale in the second period.

Second, the supplier has a cyclical requirement for operating assets (plant and equipment plus inventory) under all three methods of production. Its investment in plant and equipment is uniform over the cycle even though a plant is partially or fully idle during the off‐peak period because these are fixed assets. The supplier’s investment in inventory fluctuates over the cycle, however, because it is determined by the levels of production and sales. This inventory comprises raw materials and work in process under the first and second production alternatives because each period’s output is sold at the end of the period. The supplier’s inventory comprises raw materials, work in process, and finished goods under the third alternative because the first period’s excess production is inventoried for sale in the peak period.

Because the production alternatives share these important characteristics, the simplest alternative, a single plant with the capacity to meet peak demand, is used as the supplier’s method of production in the model. This plant is assumed to have constant returns to scale, withBequal to the cost of a unit of capacity andbequal to the cost of a unit of production, as is customary in the peak‐load pricing literature. The plant’s size is part of the solution to the supplier’s optimization problem that I describe later.

sec.label: C.
sec.title: The Supplier’s Financing Alternatives
sec.p: Common stock dividends at time 0 and time 1 equal net income at that time, while dividends at time 2 equal the liquidating dividend. Consequently, the supplier’s retained earnings equals zero, and the book value of its equity equals the owners’ initial investment. This book value is assumed to equal zero with no loss of generality.

The supplier has three alternatives for financing its operations. First, it can obtain a long‐term loan that is fully utilized the second period and hold the first period’s excess funds as financial slack. Second, the supplier can obtain a long‐term loan that is fully utilized during both periods to meet its continuing financing requirements plus a short‐term loan that is fully utilized during the second period to provide the extra financing needed in the peak period. Third, the supplier can obtain separate short‐term loans that are fully utilized during each period. The supplier chooses the method of financing that maximizes the value of its objective function.

Note that the second alternative, a mixture of short‐ and long‐term debt, is the one that matches the term to maturity of the supplier’s assets and liabilities. Guedes and Opler (1996), Stohs and Mauer (1996), and Demirgüç‐Kunt and Maksimovic (1999) documented the practice of maturity matching in their empirical tests. This model’s ability to explain maturity matching by using a mixture of short‐ and long‐term debt is therefore one of its more important features.

fn.p: Note that the presence of flotation costs causes the effective interest rate on short‐term borrowing to be higher than the interest rate on short‐term lending. This relationship is consistent with a key feature of the model of corporate liquidity that Kim, Mauer, and Sherman (1998) developed and tested.

sec.label: D.
sec.title: The Supplier’s Optimization Problem
sec.p: This model is used to analyze the effects of the supplier’s financing policy by varying the number and types of loans available to the supplier. The Lagrangian function is formed for a specific financing policy, the Kuhn‐Tucker conditions are derived, and the conditions are used to infer the long‐run marginal costs of supplying each period. Marginal revenue for periodiis set equal to marginal cost for periodi, and these equations are solved for the optimal output in each period. The supplier’s revenue, capacity, production, financing costs, and profit are computed given optimal output.

fn.p: The supplier can be thought of as a multiplant monopolist when proceeding this way: it useseq. (10)to determine total production andeq. (12)to allocate production between “plants” (periods). The supplier also can be thought of as a price‐discriminating monopolist that useseq. (10)to determine total sales andeq. (12)to allocate sales between “markets” (periods). In any case, the use of short‐term debt alters the long‐run marginal costs that appear in these optimality conditions, causing the supplier to change its output and allocate it between the periods differently.

sec.label: III.
sec.title: Financing’s Effect on the Supplier’s Long‐Run Marginal Costs
sec.p: In this section, I derive the sufficient conditions for using some short‐term debt and determine how it affects the suppliers’ long‐run marginal costs. The necessary conditions, which recognize the additional operating profit obtained by revising output in response to the change in financing, are presented later.

sec.title: Sufficient Conditions for Using Some Short‐Term Debt

Partbof proposition 1 gives the sufficient condition for using all short‐term debt rather than all long‐term debt. This condition is more likely to be satisfied the larger the term premium and the smaller the fixed and variable components of the loan initiation fee. The time pattern of demand has no effect on the choice between these two methods of financing. Consequently, any supplier may use all short‐term debt, depending on the relationship between the term premium and flotation costs, even if the same amount of financing is required during each period.

sec.label: IV.
sec.title: Short‐Term Debt’s Effect on the Supplier’s Operations and the Buyer’s Profit
sec.p: The use of some short‐term debt changes the supplier’s long‐run marginal costs, which prompts wide‐ranging changes in its operations, including its total output over the cycle, how it allocates this output between the peak and off‐peak periods, its investment in assets, and its own and the buyer’s profits. This section describes these changes without specifying which short‐term debt alternative the supplier chooses because the effects are the same whether the supplier uses a mixture of short‐ and long‐term debt or all short‐term debt. Therefore, the use of some or all short‐term debt is indicated by the subscript S hereafter.

sec.label: A.
sec.title: Short‐Term Debt’s Effect on the Supplier’s Output, Prices, and Revenue
sec.p: Proposition 3 establishes that using some short‐term debt rather than all long‐term debt causes the supplier to expand total output over the cycle and allocate more of that output to the peak period.
Proposition3.

The use of short‐term debt reduces the long‐run marginal cost of supplying the peak period because that period’s incremental production costs are no longer financed at an interest rate that includes the term premium. The supplier responds to this change by expanding total output over the cycle as required by the optimality condition given byequation (10). The use of short‐term debt also increases the long‐run marginal cost of supplying the off‐peak period because there are no idle funds then. The joint effect of these changes is to narrow the difference between MC2and MC1, reducing the supplier’s direct cost of accommodating cyclical demand. The supplier responds to this change by allocating more of its production to period 2, making greater use of its own production process rather than the buyer’s inventory to supply the peak period as required by the optimality condition given byequation (12).10

The improvement in the supplier’s ability to use its own production process rather than the buyer’s inventory to supply the peak period also is reflected in period 1 and 2’s prices. The shift of production and sales from the first to the second period causes an increase inp 1and a decrease inp 2, narrowing the difference between them. These price changes can be understood simply in terms of the changes in quantity demanded in periods 1 and 2, but there is a more informative explanation. A supplier that uses short‐term debt places less reliance on the buyer’s inventory to supply the peak period, reducing this difference. In effect, the improvement in the supplier’s ability to use its own production process to supply the peak period reduces the advantage of smoothing demand by charging a lower price in the off‐peak period. Said another way, the reduction in the supplier’s cost of supplying the peak period permits it to smooth prices rather than smooth demand.

A supplier that uses some short‐term debt sells more of its product at a lower price in the peak period and less of its product at a higher price in the off‐peak period. Proposition 4 establishes how these changes affect the supplier’s total revenue and its revenue in each period.
Proposition4.

Proposition 4 says that the use of some short‐term debt increases the supplier’s total revenue and the amplitude of the revenue cycle. These changes mirror the effects on the supplier’s output, described in proposition 3. The direct relationships between the changes in output and the changes in revenue are a consequence of the fact that the supplier is an imperfect competitor with marginal revenue greater than zero in both periods.

sec.label: B.
sec.title: Short‐Term Debt’s Effects on the Supplier’s Assets
sec.p: A supplier that uses some short‐term debt expands production and allocates more of that production to the peak period. Proposition 5 describes the effects on the supplier’s plant and equipment, inventory, and total assets.
Proposition5.

The supplier requires more plant and equipment when using some short‐term debt because peak period production and sales are larger because of the decrease in that period’s long‐run marginal costs. The supplier requires a larger raw materials inventory that is concentrated in the peak period for the same reasons. These changes increase the supplier’s investment in operating assets and magnify the amplitude of the investment cycle, which are the same effects as those on output and sales.

sec.label: C.
sec.title: Short‐Term Financing’s Total Effect on the Supplier’s Profit
sec.p: Proposition 1 established the sufficient conditions for using some short‐term debt that were based on its purely financial benefit of enabling the supplier to avoid the term premium at the expense of paying higher flotation costs. Proposition 6 establishes the necessary conditions by incorporating the higher operating profit the supplier obtains by revising its output in response to the changes in its long‐run marginal costs.

A mixture of short‐term debt is optimal in panel B, while all short‐term debt is optimal in panel C, where the term premium is highest. The supplier pays the variable component of the loan initiation fee only on the extra financing required when it uses a mixture of short‐ and long‐term loans but pays that component on the entire amount of its second‐period debt when it uses two short‐term loans. Therefore, it is economical to use all short‐term financing to avoid the term premium completely when it is large.

The supplier invests more in plant and equipment, $333.90 versus $325.35, and holds a larger inventory in period 2, $1,113.00 versus $1,084.50, to provide for the increase in the peak period’s production and sales. These changes increase the supplier’s investment in total assets during the peak period from $1,409.85 to $1,446.90 and magnify the amplitude of the total asset investment cycle. Finally, the buyer’s operating profit increases by $5.20. Substituting all short‐term debt for all long‐term debt when it is optimal to do so (panel C) produces similar changes in the supplier’s and buyer’s situations.

sec.label: VI.
sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In this study, I examined the relationships among the demand for a supplier’s product, its ensuing demand for assets, and its choice of short‐ and long‐term debt. The resulting explanation for the supplier’s financing choice is based on cyclical demand for its product and complements existing explanations based on asymmetric information, contracting costs, and taxes. In this article, I derive conditions under which a supplier will use some short‐term debt and analyze the consequences of this choice, including its effect on the supplier’s marginal costs; output; prices; revenue; investment in plant and equipment, inventory, and financial slack; financing costs; and profit. This section summarizes the model’s predictions in qualitative terms.

The study predicts that the supplier uses some short‐term debt when the savings from avoiding the term premium in long‐term interest rates plus the additional operating profit from revising its output exceed the flotation cost of a second loan. When the term premium is small, the benefits of obtaining an additional loan are small, so the supplier uses all long‐term debt. When the term premium is large, the supplier uses all short‐term debt and pays the full amount of flotation costs on two short‐term loans to avoid paying the term premium completely. For intermediate values of the term premium, the supplier uses a mixture of short‐ and long‐term debt and pays the fixed component of flotation costs on the additional loan to avoid the term premium partially. The difference between the quantity demanded in the peak and off‐peak periods is a factor in this last case, with the result that only suppliers facing cyclical demand will consider using a mixture of short‐ and long‐term debt to match the maturity of their assets and liabilities.

If these conditions are valid, then all suppliers will use short‐term debt that has zero flotation costs. The financing provided by accounts payable probably meets this restriction because trade credit is a by‐product of a sales relationship and therefore not costly to initiate.12The financing provided by bank credit lines may nearly meet this restriction if loan initiation fees are assessed for establishing the credit facility rather than for using it. Consequently, suppliers’ accounts payable and outstanding balances under revolving credit agreements are predicted to follow the same cycle as the demand for the supplier’s product.

Suppliers that can obtain sufficient financial or operating benefits will pay the loan initiation fee and use other forms of short‐term debt in addition to accounts payable and short‐term debt that does not have flotation costs. The financial benefit of using a mixture of short‐ and long‐term debt is directly related to the size of the term premium, the variable cost of production, and the strength of the sales cycle. Therefore, suppliers are more likely to use a mixture of short‐ and long‐term debt to match the maturity of their assets and liabilities when there is a large difference between peak and off‐peak demand, their variable cost ratio is high, and the yield curve is steep. Guedes and Opler (1996) and Stohs and Mauer (1996) have already documented the existence of the predicted term premium effect.

The operating benefit of using some short‐term debt, which is the additional operating profit the supplier earns by expanding total output and allocating more of this output to the peak period, is directly related to the elasticity of demand for the supplier’s product. This elasticity is larger when there are fewer substitutes for the supplier's product, so suppliers that sell essential or even crucial inputs are more likely to satisfy the necessary condition and use some short‐term debt. Finally, the reduction in interest costs or the increase in operating profits is more likely to exceed the loan initiation fee when the supplier is large.

The model predicts that the use of short‐term debt has wide‐ranging consequences for the supplier’s operations and investments. First, the model predicts that suppliers that use some short‐term debt have higher total output and revenue over the cycle. This change is produced by increases in peak period output and revenue that more than offset decreases in off‐peak period output and revenue. The resulting increase in the amplitudes of the output and revenue cycles is accompanied by a decrease in the amplitude of the price cycle, as peak period prices are lower and off‐peak period prices are higher. All of these changes are consequences of short‐term debt’s effect on the supplier’s long‐run marginal costs, which make it more economical for the supplier to use its own production process instead of the buyer’s inventory to accommodate cyclical demand.

Second, the model predicts that suppliers that use short‐term debt have larger investments in plant, equipment, and inventory to support the changes in output. Their investment in plant and equipment is uniform over the cycle because production facilities are fixed assets, but their investment inventory is concentrated in the peak period to support that period’s sales. The net effect is an increase in the cyclicality of the supplier’s operating assets. These predictions apply whether the supplier’s method of production is one plant with the capacity to meet peak demand (as assumed in this article), two plants, or one plant with the capacity to meet average demand and a finished goods inventory. The composition of the supplier’s investment in plant, equipment, and inventory under the latter two production policies is different, but the use of short‐term debt has the same effects.

Third, the model predicts that suppliers that use short‐term debt maintain less financial slack during the off‐peak period because they have no excess financing then. This smoothing of the supplier’s investment in financial slack is more than offset by the increase in the cyclicality of operating assets, causing an increase in the cyclical behavior of the supplier’s total assets.

Stated succinctly, this study predicts that the use of some short‐term debt increases the supplier’s size, whether measured by revenue or total assets; increases the amplitude of the supplier’s sales, inventory, and total assets cycles; and decreases the cyclicality of prices and financial slack. Furthermore, this study predicts that there is a high degree of correspondence among the cyclical patterns in the demand for the supplier’s product, its investment in assets, and its financing, Guedes and Opler (1996), Stohs and Mauer (1996), and Demirgüç‐Kunt and Maksimovic (1999) already found that companies match the term to maturity of their assets and liabilities, as predicted.

Finally, this study predicts that the optimal use of short‐term debt increases the supplier’s profit by increasing its operating income and reducing its financing costs. The buyer obtains a similar increase in its operating profit if demand for the supplier’s product is sufficiently inelastic.

This explanation for the choice of debt maturity complements existing theories because it is concerned with the systematic use of short‐term debt to finance cyclical variations in production and sales rather than the effects of asymmetric information, contracting costs, or taxes. This study provides an additional basis for some of the predictions obtained from other theories, but, more important, it provides entirely new predictions about the interrelationships among a company’s financing choice and its investments and operations.
